{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3376453,"name":"Chris","username":"Chris_7898","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chris_7898/{size}/226133_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-29T13:52:56.565Z","cooked":"

I’m new to Java and CTRE motors but is there a way to run a Kraken motor with RPM? Also, how could I feed an RPM value into the code from something like shuffleboard? I’m open to any examples or explanations!

How could I feed rpm values in from shuffleboard with that code?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-04-29T13:56:54.110Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":364,"readers_count":363,"score":92.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464847,"topic_slug":"krakenx60-motors-with-rpm","display_username":"Chris","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":25951,"username":"Technologyman00","name":"Technologyman00","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/technologyman00/{size}/178178_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60542,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5561 Prog Lead"},"post_url":"/t/krakenx60-motors-with-rpm/464847/3","custom_user_title":"5561 Prog Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3377484,"name":"Yishai Levy","username":"levyishai","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/levyishai/{size}/264719_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-30T20:14:49.314Z","cooked":"

To read a value from shuffleboard, use SmartDashboard.getNumber("path", defaultNumber);
Then, assuming you already tuned the velocity control gains, apply them using
motor.setControl(new VelocityVoltage(velocityRotationsPerSecond));
With a complete code, it’ll look something like this:

double targetRPM = SmartDashboard.getNumber("RPM", 0);
double rotationsPerSecond = targetRPM / 60; // converting from rotations per minute to per second.
motor.setControl(new VelocityVoltage(rotationsPerSecond));

Edit: divide, not multiply

Besides our VelocityClosedLoop example, you can also check out our Closed-Loop Overview and Basic PID and Profiling to get an idea of how to use velocity control with our devices.

levyishai:

double rotationsPerSecond = targetRPM * 60; // converting from rotations per minute to per second.

Note that you want to divide RPM by 60 to get RPS, not multiply. 6000 RPM = 100 RPS.

is there a way to add a ramp up time to that now?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-04-30T21:53:07.928Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":148,"readers_count":147,"score":39.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":464847,"topic_slug":"krakenx60-motors-with-rpm","display_username":"Chris","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57809,"username":"levyishai","name":"Yishai Levy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/levyishai/{size}/264719_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60542,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5561 Prog Lead"},"post_url":"/t/krakenx60-motors-with-rpm/464847/7","custom_user_title":"5561 Prog Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3377557,"name":"Yishai Levy","username":"levyishai","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/levyishai/{size}/264719_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-30T21:57:16.257Z","cooked":"

There are three main ways to do this:

  • Add a really strong current limit. Though you can’t control the exact time. I believe it’s in a StatorCurrentConfig or something.
  • Change the closed loop ramp rate, though it’s also limited and not fully controlable. Don’t remember where the setting for that is
  • Most idealy, use MotionMagicVelocityVoltage (though the hardest to tune)

I was able to find the closed loop ramp rates in the TalonFXConfig file

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-04-30T22:02:14.353Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":127,"readers_count":126,"score":40.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":464847,"topic_slug":"krakenx60-motors-with-rpm","display_username":"Chris","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57809,"username":"levyishai","name":"Yishai Levy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/levyishai/{size}/264719_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60542,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5561 Prog Lead"},"post_url":"/t/krakenx60-motors-with-rpm/464847/9","custom_user_title":"5561 Prog Lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3377564,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-30T22:09:22.693Z","cooked":"

I would recommend against using closed-loop ramp rates to limit acceleration, as it also impacts the response of the PID controller. Instead, I would recommend using Motion Magic® Velocity. Compared to regular velocity PID, the only changes are to set the MotionMagicAcceleration config (and optionally jerk) and use a MotionMagicVelocity control request.
